weblinks.title: Have an Oculus Rift and Leap Motion? Try This Web VR Demo Right Now
weblinks.intro: Mozilla is making impressive progress in bringing virtual reality to the web. Today I got to see a surreal new experience that makes use of the Oculus Rift and the Leap Motion directly in the web browser.

weblinks.title: Reinventing the Web in Virtual Reality with Josh Carpenter and Vladimir Vukicevic
weblinks.intro: What could a cross-platform web of Virtual Reality look like? What might web designers do with a fully-immersive web experience? There's a team at Mozilla working on WebVR. Jen Simmons talks to Josh Carpenter and Vladimir Vukicevic to find out what they are doing.

weblinks.title: Scientific American on Future of WebVR
weblinks.intro: Backed by Google and Mozilla, VR-enabled browsers and gear could soon immerse Web users in 3-D worlds

weblinks.title: CODAME Interview: Josh Carpenter on Web VR
weblinks.intro: CODAME is bringing their VR artists to Mozilla HQ November 21st because Mozilla has just released VR enabled builds of Firefox. Why is Mozilla getting into VR?

weblinks.title: Wemo Labs Interview: Josh Carpenter on web VR
weblinks.intro: Josh Carpenter of Mozilla speaks to Wemo.io about VR on the web

weblinks.title: Presentation: VR & The Web: Next Steps
weblinks.intro: A presentation by Josh and Vlad on the current status of the VR web, and a preview of Mozilla's latest experiments.

weblinks.title: Voices of VR Podcast: Josh Carpenter on the future of the VR web
weblinks.intro: Upcoming VR experiments from Mozilla including collaborative web browsing with TogetherJS

weblinks.title: Presentation: Virtual Reality & The Future of the Web
weblinks.intro: A presentation by Josh and Vlad on the future of the open web.

weblinks.title: Voices of VR Podcast: Vlad Vukicevic on bringing VR to the web platform
weblinks.intro: Creating a plug-in free experience with Unity & UE4, and the future of responsive web deign for VR
